content:
Posted: March 25
												I bought this game thinking I will have a great time since I read so many good reviews about it. I am not sure if my copy was possessed or if it was just the way it was meant to be. Either way, I only keep it in my library to remind myself that I need to make better choices in life. What exactly was wrong with the game? It wasn't just one thing. It was a bunch of small things that slowly angered me until I was utterly infuriated. The gameplay I experienced can only be described like this: It's like trying to stick your fork into the last pea on your plate. Whenever you think you got it the thing rolls away and you're left wondering why you've been punished. Similarly, it also leaves you feeling unsatisfied. Sure, you have the whole game. But that one last bite is still missing. That something was the soul of a theme park. I never actually felt as if I was playing a theme park simulator. It was simply too boring. I've always been a fan of tycoon games but I've never felt so enraged by a game in my life. I played through all the tutorials, read everything and made sure I understood everything. Yet the paths...the paths were acting like freaking hoodlums. Breaking whenever I thought I finally managed to build the path correctly and will be able to open the ride. But just as I tried to open the ride...bam...the freaking path trolled me again by breaking. Then I fixed the path...only for it to break in another location. I googled this and realized other people also have this issue. I tried to follow their recommendations...I really tried. I never managed to get past two rides because that path be failing every time. Everything in the game takes too much time. Going through the menu takes time, building things takes forever. (And don't think you'll be building awesome rides at first because that takes too long). Seriously, I get that there's a bit of a learning curve but after a while that just fails to excite. After all, I play games so I can instill the fake belief that I'm actually good at things, not to remind myself that I can't get my act together in a game either. I could still deal with all the time consuming parts in the game, the swarm of bugs and long tutorials, if it wasn't for the paths. I know I mentioned it before but I cannot stress enough how much the paths ruined my life. It was a when a path screamed its final hoorah and broke one time too many that I flew into a rage and uninstalled the game. Whenever I think about this game and the money I spent on it I become so horribly enraged. I'm normally a calm person but I doubt anything I can say will ever be able to capture the pure passion with which I hate this game. I truly wish I had a physical copy of this game. Why? So I can either A. rip it to shreds while I cry from frustration or B. eat it and have my body dissolve it into the poop that it was to me.

number of helpful: 8 of 28 people (29%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 2, 2014
												I was really excited to finally play a RCT game after nearly fourteen years, even more so after the original game disks for RCT2 wouldn't load properly on my computer. However, I became pretty confused at the menus for the game and on how to simply do things in the game.For starters, there is NO HOT KEYS programmed into the game. Another review mentions that you can rotate the camera with two keys, and then you can move around the map with the directional keys (or asdw). But that is IT. How they set it up to make the roller coasters themselves would be MUCH easier if you could use the directional keys. I lost count on how many times I had to delete tracks because I accidentally did it wrong because of the cumbersome interface.Let me say that again: it's confusing to make roller coasters in this game. Considering it's RollerCoaster Tycoon, that isn't a good thing. If your roller coaster happens to go underground, if you delete it, it doesn't undo the large hole in the ground. If you make a roller coaster too tall, it doesn't tell you it's too tall; it just says you can't build there, which causes some confusion as you try to go around it all. Messing with the ground is one of the most frustrating thing ever. Last night, I was able to make a pretty cool body of water under my roller coaster. Hours later, I decided to make a ferry in that lake to get to the other side. For some reason, I then couldn't edit the ground that I had edited earlier to make that lake; I actually could not make a deeper lake for my ferry to really go by. Then I had loads of trouble making paths that actually lined up with the buildings and rides. For at least an hour, I didn't realize that people couldn't go to the shops I made because the path "didn't line up" with it. People got stuck on pathways around there, so I had to tinker around with the path for at least thirty minutes just to get it right.The menus are just terrible here. Constantly I just pressed around until I got what I wanted. And with no hot keys, it made the process even more tedious than it should have been.So bottom line: I am playing this game, and I will be playing it more. But I am really disappointed in the controls and interface. I only played it on sandbox, where I have unlimited money; I can't imaging playing it and actually trying to make a profit. It was cool making that one roller coaster and "riding" it, and of course it's always fun to make that death roller coaster and watching people scatter and fall out of it. But I can't see me actually trying to make a successful park out of this. I'd rather try to get RCT2 working again.

												It seems like a decent game if you like the old style tycoon games. I didn't enjoy it though, the UI was excruciatingly tiny, random and difficult to use. Constantly getting frustrated with the weird controls and having to close every single window in the UI manually one for one was very irritating. There is no indication (or I didn't see any) of whether you are losing money or gaining so you would just have to wait for a real long time and see for yourself by constantly staring at your available money. The controls are unnecessarily difficult and useless. If you like old games then you'll probably like this one, the heavily outdated game controls and engine are very distasteful to me, (even though it is old and limited by the time) it felt almost lazy in developing better user friendly controls and UI. If there was a remake to fix all these problems then I'll maybe consider it...

content:
Posted: August 6, 2014
												I love the original Rollercoaster Tycoon and was pleased to move up to 3 when given the option by a friend.   At first glance, it's pretty, nicely updated, a great step forward.  The sheer amount of stuff you could build was impressive and lord the options.  There was so many gentle rides and a plethora of restaurants to choose from, you could almost build a full park from their options alone.The water rides got a nice increase, with way more choices and little things like fireworks, scenery options, and zoo attractions where nice and should have been included way earlier than this (Like in the first game).Then I got into the game play of actually building a park and rides and discovered just how much I truly hated this version of the game.  I found the controls to be extremely frustrating, which in the end, left me uninstalling it and going back to the original where I apparently belong. A makeover in graphics and more options doesn't make a better game.  Seriously... why was it that hard to build a simple ride line...

content:
Posted: June 3, 2015
												I had a few friends rave about RollerCoaster Tycoon and decided to give it a try when it was on sale.  I played Sim Theme Park when I was younger and had a blast with it and I hoped that RollerCoaster Tycoon would fill that void.  I was wrong.  While this game boasts some serious depth with regards to how many different types of rollercoasters, rides, and scenery you can build, those items seem irrelevant while playing (they are just for you, the AI doesn't notice it too much) and don't make up for the game's basic functionality shortcomings.The first problem I experienced was building a rollercoaster is a serious time investment.  While that is fun at first, I spent a very long time just trying to complete the circuit, which is arguably the least fun part of building a coaster.  Then I had to create the entrance and exit and found myself spending more time creating a working queue that fit with my coaster design yet still didn't attract enough riders to fill it even a quarter of the way up.My trouble really stems from the user interface for RollerCoaster Tycoon.  All the buttons are quite cryptic (just tiny icons that you have to memorize.  For example, the guest list icon has a wrench on it, which is easily confused with the staff icon, which also has a wrench on it) and I was unable to easily find hotkeys for basic tasks such as deletion, which is a two click operation each time.  The escape key, which in most games just exits the last or top-most open menu, always prompts you whether to leave your current game.  It is as if the interface designers hadn't ever played other games and made their own independent system, putting the responsibility on the user to learn how to play.The other half of my issues comes from excessive depth in construction.  As I said before, I must have spent an hour creating a path because I wasn't allowed to build it under certain segments of my coaster, while I could under other segments.  I do accept some blame for not thinking through my design, but I came from the Sim Theme Park universe, where I could have fun creating a rollercoaster and would spend more time making money from it than from building the entrances and exits.  This problem extends to shops and kiosks where if you don't toggle the "auto-levelling" feature (which should arguably be toggled on by default), even if it is up against a path, the ignorant AI can't get to the food or items.Overall, RollerCoaster Tycoon is a headache with its strange interface and picky construction rules.  I had some fun with it, but my last game was so annoying that I had to write this review.  Sim Theme Park was a great example of a fun and deep theme park game.  Yes, it was a bit cartoony and maybe even a little childish, but the interface and construction guidance allowed for some serious creativity and challenging gameplay.  Rather than frustration over how to finish your coaster and get the entrance sorted out, SimTheme Park allowed you to focus on goals of each mission.

content:
Posted: January 26, 2014
												It's addicting and fun for a while, but the major irritations ruin the enire game for me. I never was able to build a coaster that actually worked. Any slight incline, despite a powered launch and every attempt aiding the cart to be able to go up, caused the damn thing to roll backwards. I could not figure out how to connect the exit of Crazy Golf to a path. Once you try to change the surrface terrain and you screw up, fixing your mistake can be impossible to figure out. So do I recommend this game? Not really. I'd love to try a new Roller Coaster Tycoon game with updated capabilities and much much easier controls.

number of helpful: 10 of 34 people (29%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 29, 2013
												I bought "Roller Coaster Tycoon 3: Platinum!" in a weak moment. Here's a game that I've wanted to play for years, because, you know, in 2004 it sounded like fun, and "Tycoon" games were all the rage back then. But the price has been artificially high since forever, and I've always had something better to play. Finally on Steam, and finally a daily sale, in 2013. Unfortunately, I didn't really enjoy this game. Too much tutorial, not enough game. I stuck around long enough to learn how to make my own coaster and ride in first-person view, and TBH that's all I really wanted to do. :-DI scratched that itch, but I won't be back. Enjoy my $4, Steam.

number of helpful: 24 of 66 people (36%) found this review helpful4 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: July 16, 2013
												Ugh. I really shouldn't be suprised. Everything in this game felt soulless and even hostile at times. I can only visualize the developers of this game as some sort of corporate zombies, tasked to emulate Roller Coaster Tycoon using New Three D Technology(tm). No thought was put into this game. nothing new. nothing original. nobody asking, "What's the best way to implement this feature that would be the most pleasing/ interesting/ convenient for the user?"       The UI was the first sign that something was horribly wrong. Almost all of the menus are on the lefthand side of the screen in a long unlabled column of vague icons which, when clicked, open up another long unlabeled column of icons. I'm sure with a little effort, I could memorize what each of the icons does, but why bother? Nothing in this game is thought out or intuitive. There's no sensible organization to the list of icons. Maybe I'll try to get around it by using hot keys? "HAHA! WHAT ARE HOTKEYS? THIS IS THE FUTURE, HERE IN THE FUTURE THERE IS ONLY ONE BUTTON AND A POINTY TRIANGLE." Really. All I can do with my keyboard is rotate the camera, Q and E. Two buttons.        Need to toggle on/off trees so I can see where I'm building my path? Lefthand column. Video controls. Toggle scenery off.... Wait... That toggles everything off? Even raised paths and rides? And they're totally invisible now? Not even a shadow to see what I'm connecting to? I just wanted to turn off trees!       But wait! there's a third key on the keyboard that woks! It's escape! No matter where you are in the game, pressing escape will bring up a box asking if you want to quit. The yes button is higlighted. The game knows. It begs to be put to rest, and forgotten into the oblivion of time. Let it's ancestors stand tall in the glory of thier nostalgic memory, but please let the world forget the bottomless misery of the last ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ child of the  Roller Coaster Tycoon line. Sleep now poor soul. May oblivion take you painlessly.

number of helpful: 3 of 19 people (16%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: September 25, 2015
												They made it worse than Roller Coaster Tycoon 2. Employees quit which is a neat idea but they never tell you why so spending anytime organizing your staff feels like a gamble because they might just leave. Also they took out the ability to just start with an empty park, a loan and a dream. You can only play Career mode situations or sandbox. All I wanted to do was build my own park and that's just not allowed unless you ignore money which is just not a challenge at all. Also the UI is somehow worse, RCT2 made sense to me with it's menus and hotkeys in this game I didn't find any useful hotkeys and the menus feel clunky trying to find certain things. This I admit would get better with time but I won't be putting time into this game. It's still Roller Coaster Tycoon just a bit worse.

number of helpful: 4 of 22 people (18%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 9, 2014
												5/10 Ever played a RCT game before? Me too, then I got the gamer's high and figured I'd try this old horse out again with all the shiny updates, new cover and a number "3" instead of a number "2" at the end of the title.What a waste of money.It's just as laggy and mindless as I remember, which some people like, I grant you, but I am not one of those types. This is an excellent game for a child under the age of 14 who is just breaking into a real gaming PC, but maybe FPSs or RTSs are too complicated; or the machine you're using is so out-dated that this is the only game you can play. Honestly, I see no real changes to this edition when I put it aside RCT 2. The graphics are nicer and more smooth, but all the employees, rides, options and flavour is the exact same. Sure the "story" mode has different maps and settings, but at the end of the day you're just running another crappy amusment park, advertising in the same venues, and figuring out the best way to rip off faceless droves of NPCs just enough that you gouge them without turning them away. It's a micro-manager's wet dream much in the same way that EVE is, but very much without the rewarding sense of accomplishment or space lasers.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 5, 2015
												RCT 3 is a major step forward in the RCT franchise and adds so much more to the game that it would be very hard to be bored with this game. Being able to now ride the rides was a much needed necessity and added so much depth to the game itself. The larger park size was enough to create any playground of fun without running out of room for expansion. Bringing forward most of the features that were in the previous title, it still feels very much like and has the touch of a RCT game.Now with that said, it does have some drawbacks. The cartoonish peeps are just not as vibrant as the little peeps in RCT2. The peep interaction in RCT 2 feels more fun and vibrating. Building roller coasters in RCT 2 felt more fun and puzzling. That's not to say that RCT 3 coasters were dull, because they weren't. they just lacked the circus fun that RCT 2 had. Creating buildings in RCT 3 had more options and became easier and felt more real. Adding billboards added to the realism of real life parks and made a major difference in aesthetic pleasure. Being able to create your own fireworks show with the Mixmaster was a major step forward and added an extra layer to building a awesome park and helped bring the park alive, something that RCT 2, at times, lacked.The water and animal expansion packs helped bring the game to full circle, allowing versatility in building any kind of theme park that you could imagine. Being able to create pools was another needed must have that the game deserved and gave the ability to choose what kind of Theme Park you wanted to create from an animal park to just a water park to a coaster haven. RCT 3 is a complete game with three games wrapped into one.  There is no question that Frontier Developments brought the series to a new level which gave you the option to never get bored with game. Hours on end, there is no question that RCT 3 is a winner is all aspects and changed the series forever upping the ante on how future versions would be crafted and created. 5 stars out of 5 stars. Highly recommended for die-hard fans of the series.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 26, 2013
												Without a single doubt, RCT3 is a time consuming, coaster building, amusement gaining good time. Though a few things that made RCT2 unique are not present in this one, there's still more than enough to settle for. The game comes with all the expansion packs; Soaked, and Wild, both with an acceptable amount of new features. The transition to 3D looks rather dated up close, but from a distance it appears to look similar to some tycoon games on the new market today, but of course this would be the least graphically advanced of the bunch. Though campaigns are laughably shorter than the previous titles, this feels like a good move because something the previous installments lacked was the ability to keep the player caring on a single map with the limited choices to make for around four hours on a first run. Instead, you'll be on a map for around a good hour and that's the perfect amount of time you need before it begins to get dull. When you move to another map, the experience is always renewed because of how many new options you obtain. Sandbox mode is here for new players to experiment around with endless money and restrictions, so you can jump right in and learn for yourself. Tutorial sessions are also available. Replayability is a sweet refreshment to this game because the Platinum edition itself is around a good 35 hours, and with the ability to be creative on sandbox, complete all the tycoon challenges, and the map editor (you heard me right!) the game will never get old. If you can get over it's childish appeal, (and as an "unmentioned" comment, the land editing mechanics) it's here to give you literally endless hours of solid entertainment.8.5/10

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 26, 2013
												Having never been a fan of "management" games like SimCity I came into RCT3 a little worried that I'd become overwhelmed and eventually bored by too much micromanaging. Happy to say that was not the case at all here! The game lets you access sandbox mode and every single coaster, attraction, bathroom stall, right from the get-go, allowing you to get a feel for the game before you even start career mode.The game feels more focused on park-creation rather than micro-managing. Rarely do I ever really adjust things like ride-prices or hire/fire staff frequently. You can upgrade staff members up to 2 levels, making them faster and more efficient which means you don't need as many of that type of staff.There's a nice level of customization as well. You can import custom music (though .wma files seem to only work for me) and custom pictures for things like billboards or customized sale stalls. There's also a decent variety of colors for the rides but I felt like the palette was very bland, it can either feel too boring or too bright. You can also import/export coasters and build your own scenarios. There are also tons of mods and additions you can find through different resources and communities online.The addictive part is when you start scenarios in career mode and begin building a park the way you want it. The game gives you very basic objectives such as "Have X amount of attendance in the park" or "Get X approval rating" and usually these can be accomplished anytime. Meanwhile while you manage, you research into more attractions and coaster-types you can add. It's so entertaining watching "Peeps" ride your creations and you feel accomplished when you make something your virtual guests enjoy.Some of the game's controls are a bit odd. I was kinda surprised by the lack of any sort of "undo" button, so it gets a bit annoying if you accidentally delete something or put something down you didn't want. I also ran into issues that weren't explained well by the game, and had trouble figuring out how to build certain things. Google wasn't exactly the first place I wanted to go to get answers, but thankfully it was more than enough help. Just a few minor gripes, but hasn't stopped me from playing. If you haven't played it before I definitely recommend it. Just expect to be at your computer for a few hours at a time; It's incredibly addictive!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: September 22, 2014
												So yeah, Roller Coaster Tycoon. What can you even say about it really? It's a classic game series that pretty much boosted tycoon games (Other than Sim City) to more heights. So with the passage of time, Infograms we're bought out by atari and the original creator, Chris Sawyer, not working on it anymore, Atari tried to make there own RCT game; and this is how Roller Coaster Tycoon 3 came to be known as... an okay game.So I guess I have to say the pros and cons about it, soooooooooooooooooooooo...The game is now in 3D, and it works pretty well. The only real problem is trying to turn the camera up and down trying to find the perfect angle; It just resets and goes back to a semi top down perspective. The main focus of the game is that you can RIDE the RIDES, and you can kinda ride the rides, but not in the people or "peep's" point of view. Instead It's on the cart's point of view. Because the rides have feelings too you know. The gameplay is you're tipical tycoon game. But don't go building your rollercoaster of death and spooky scary skeletons, you see this game has an antagonist. The Park Inspector. He hate's everything fun and will make you throw out your anger on the keyboard. You're roller coaster is a little bit unsafe? SHUT IT DOWN! Water slide landing in the wrong pool? SHUT IT DOWN! He really makes the game less fun and you can't take him out. Also, you can't kill people in the game. I guess it makes the game more casualized since there's no worry of screwing up your coaster. Oh and one more thing to add. The zoo expansion is just Zoo Tycoon so just ask someone how Zoo Tycoon plays and that's RCT 3's Zoo expansion in a nutshell. The Water expansion just adds pools which don't really need an explanation. Same with Water Slides.So yeah, It's an okay game but not as good as the other games in the series. Really, if it was it's own game without the RCT game I think I would have liked it more, not to say It's a bad game. But with the price, I don't recommend it. Wait for a sale to get it, trust me you'll thank me later.

content:
Posted: September 5, 2013
												For those who relish in nostalgia, or for those just coming across it, Roller Coaster Tycoon is the quintessential tycoon game. The third installment in the series far surpasses the second, but is almost a different breed than the first. Not to argue that it isn't an improvement, simply that the two games seem to offer quite a unique playing style while both being part of the same franchise. The ability to ride coasters in a first-person view, is a welcome addition in this version of the game. The fireworks mixmaster disply is decent enough, however there seems to be some lacking instructional material that covers the laser light show side of the same rig. Nevertheless, Roller Coaster Tycoon 3 is a very solid purchase and a classic addition to any game library. Four stars.

												I remember playing the first Rollercoaster Tycoon as a kid with my sister. Good old nostalgia tempted me into buying this when it was on sale one day, and I've never regretted the decision. RollerCoaster Tycoon is a simple game with a simple objective: you build a theme park. While you can play the campaign and aim for creating a profitable park and meet certain objectives, you can also opt to play the sandbox mode instead. Aside from the sandbox mode, there is also the scenario builder. You can create your own perameters for how you want to play the game. Do you want certain weather or infinite money? Go for it. RollerCoaster Tycoon might be on the older side, but it is certainly a game that can be enjoyed by any age.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: September 22, 2014
												So yeah, Roller Coaster Tycoon. What can you even say about it really? It's a classic game series that pretty much boosted tycoon games (Other than Sim City) to more heights. So with the passage of time, Infograms we're bought out by atari and the original creator, Chris Sawyer, not working on it anymore, Atari tried to make there own RCT game; and this is how Roller Coaster Tycoon 3 came to be known as... an okay game.So I guess I have to say the pros and cons about it, soooooooooooooooooooooo...The game is now in 3D, and it works pretty well. The only real problem is trying to turn the camera up and down trying to find the perfect angle; It just resets and goes back to a semi top down perspective. The main focus of the game is that you can RIDE the RIDES, and you can kinda ride the rides, but not in the people or "peep's" point of view. Instead It's on the cart's point of view. Because the rides have feelings too you know. The gameplay is you're tipical tycoon game. But don't go building your rollercoaster of death and spooky scary skeletons, you see this game has an antagonist. The Park Inspector. He hate's everything fun and will make you throw out your anger on the keyboard. You're roller coaster is a little bit unsafe? SHUT IT DOWN! Water slide landing in the wrong pool? SHUT IT DOWN! He really makes the game less fun and you can't take him out. Also, you can't kill people in the game. I guess it makes the game more casualized since there's no worry of screwing up your coaster. Oh and one more thing to add. The zoo expansion is just Zoo Tycoon so just ask someone how Zoo Tycoon plays and that's RCT 3's Zoo expansion in a nutshell. The Water expansion just adds pools which don't really need an explanation. Same with Water Slides.So yeah, It's an okay game but not as good as the other games in the series. Really, if it was it's own game without the RCT game I think I would have liked it more, not to say It's a bad game. But with the price, I don't recommend it. Wait for a sale to get it, trust me you'll thank me later.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 9, 2014
												RCT3 is potentially one of my favorite games. I've been a roller coaster lover since I was a kid, so maybe it's that.The game has multiple scenarios you can play through, or mess around in a sandbox or custom scenario. There is no store where you can buy things with real money, everything is in the game. Another plus is this is platinum edition, so you get access to the Wild expandsion pack and the Soaked expansion pack, both adding quite a few things to the game.Of course, you can construct any roller coaster you would like for your park, or select a premade one. You can also save your coasters to use in a different game, or perhaps even a RCT4.The graphics are fairly well, being a decade old game, except the people in the game have blocky faces, though this can be quite funny.The finance system is extremely designed. You have to hire janitors and mechanics, and you have to pay them a salary. Shops and rollercoasters cost money to run, so you need to make sure that the amount of money they are pulling in from the people outweighs the running cost, otherwise you will go into debt. You can also run ad campains to advertise your park and have people come visit. These include coupons for specific rides, a get in free coupon, or just a plain advertisement. Of course, these cost money, just like they would in real life, so you can't spend all your savings on ad campains.Overall an extremely fun game which has a good finance system and if you love roller coasters, you will love this game to death.9.5/10did i mention you can ride your coasters?

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 4, 2014
												One of the worst - no wait - the worst installment of the Roller Coaster Tycoon franchise. If you played the original, first version from 1999 and valued it for its simple yet multifaceted gameplay then this game will badly crush your dreams. Ugly as hell 3D graphics - even for 2005 standards - and an interface so clumsy that you can destroy a painstakingly constructed rollercoaster with just one click. It wasn't developed by Chris Sawyer directly anymore like its predecessors. It was said that he had just taken a consulting position. Obviously that either didn't help or they didn't really consult him at all.If you're thinking about buying this in a Steam sale (like I did), save yourself the money and buy and awesome indie game instead.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: March 21, 2016
												Played this game as a kid for many many hour, absolutely fantastic. Though I have to say I can't really recommend getting any particular Roller Coaster Tycoon game over another, just wait 'till they're on sale and get them all, they're all really good! If you do like the ability to look around in 3D maybe you'll like this better, but I have found myself liking RCT2 better than 3 at times because in 3 the 3D gets complicated for me, vs the isometric view (which to be fair you can enable in RCT3) that allows you to not have to worry about camera angles too much. But on the contrary navigating eveything in 3D is way cool too. I don't know, this is a hard review for me to write, and I can't really say much useful except that if you like any RCT you should like this one too, they're all complimentary to each other. And RCT the original just has this awesome nostalgia with the low res graphics and music that's unforgettable. Just get them all!

												I searched my bank account looking for the 89 Million I'd need to build my dream rollercoaster- namely one that ascends 500 feet followed by a 90 degree drop into an unfinished section that dumps the coaster onto a walkway where my meandering park guests walk back and forth.  Then it hit me- I could have my dream for the price of a few McDonald's value meals and not worry about the real life death and destruction my idea would cause (plus I couldn't find the 89m)!  This game is so fun even if it is over half a decade old.  I wish they'd come out with the updated version already!  But if you are a builder and looking for a great deal on a fun game then just go for it! You'll love RCT3 Platinum.

												Addictive would be the word for this game. In an arena where you have to manage, and build, yet are still able to exercise your creativity, the possibilities are endless. Build the theme park of your dreams, try to top the ones you've been to already, or just try to figure out ways to make heaps of money in as many ways possible!I've read comments about the graphics; personally, I don't mind. The 3D makes the rides look amazing, and the little details in the landscape really make the whole thing pop. All in all, lots of fun!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 13, 2015
												Do not be fooled by the hours in this game on Steam. I have spent many of hours on this game ever since 2008 in a box retail version.How do I sum this game up?Well, this game is all about making Roller Coasters, right? It's in the title. Well, it is that, but it's way more than building roller coasters. You mainly build theme parks for people to enjoy in. Mostly, building coasters, rides, food stalls, and basically maintaining a theme park.To start out, I'd recommend you play in Sandbox mode so you can fool around with the editor. You have unlimited money and you start out on a superflat world with the biggest park size. There, you can build your park. Add roller coasters, make carousells, make other flat rides, as well as making food and drink stalls, with other things. The Platinum version of the game adds in the 2 other expansion packs: Soaked! and Wild!. Soaked adds in pools, more coasters, the ability to build underground, and more stuffs. Wild adds in the ability to make enclosures to house animals of many kinds, coasters, rides, and more. With these things all togeather, you can make a Mega Park/WaterPark/Zoo.But if you are willing for a challange, try out the career mode, where you are given a scenario, and you have to complete the objectives before you can move on. Most of the scenario parks are given to you in the beginning, but to unlock the later ones, you have to reach a certain level in each park. It's tricky. Sadly, you won't gain anything for this except pre-made roller coaster designs, but for people wanting a challenge, go for it. There's different parks for each expansion pack, so you can play all the levels.This game was also important to me because this was my 1st real PC game in 2008, and I made 70+ parks on my crappy old Vista desktop. Too many hours to count on this game, and now I got it on Steam.You thought it stopped with the game? Nope, because out there on the wild internet you can find custom content. Custom coasters, flat rides, and most importantly, custom scenery. These mods make your game look better than with the stock scenery. Mods include coaster supports, lights, catwalks, fences, and much more. Also, they made an invisible ride entrance and exit, so you arn't stuck with the stupid stock ones. There's a wealth of mods out there, and lots of tutorials on how to install them. I will also be providing a link to a Steam guide to all of the mods I use, so you can see the stuff I like.All in all, RCT3 is one of the greatest games out there. If you are new to the RCT series, this game is the easiest to get into, then you can discover the first 2 games. There's also a 4th game in the process of being made, called World. Anything that this game didn't have will be added in World, and that comes to the bad things about this game.First, like the first 2 games, your whole park is like a giant grid system. Each grid block at a certain height will be taken up when you place something there. Although this is great for beginners, it's not that great for people that want to be creative. You just want to move this wall 2 inches to connect to the other wall, but you can't. Second, probably due to the game engine being from 2004, if you zoom away from an object, they have the chance of dissapearing. And also compared to todays standards, everything looks a bit blocky. Depending on your computer likes and dislikes, this game might not even work! If you get this game, you have to be willing to mess with the settings to get the most out of it for your machine.To end this rambling, this game is amazing. Just spend $20 and get it. I got about $35 in RCT3 stuff alone, with getting the base game and expansion packs alone, and then getting this combo copy on Steam. That shows you how much I like this game.9/10 You can charge people to go to the bathroom!

												This isn't a very challanging game but it's a great sandbox. It offers plenty of options for building your park and is suprisingly cinematic at times. You can spend hours and hours designing and beautifying your park or creating tounge-in-cheek rides synched to your favourite(or not) tunes. The terrain tools, building options, and general openess allows the player a lot of freedom to play however they want to, even beyond the confines of 'amusement park simulator'.I build racetracks out of paths and run over my guests with the dune buggy.10/10 who needs NASCAR

content:
Posted: August 28, 2015
												After 20 hours its time for a reviewThis game right off the bat feels nostalgic. I never had the expansions so this is great. The start menu is a bit bland, just un-appealing photos but that doesnt matter.I got into the game and I instantley decided to make a wild west park, after hours of work I had my base park down a coaster and some carnival rides and I was hooked like I used to be. I decided to download some maps and they are great. Some cons are the fact that some coasters are odd to build, an example is on the tilt coaster on one of the special pieces instead of slowing down it keeps moving and crashes. Overall I see no reason not to buy this.Pros-Once you make 1 or 2 good coasters its easy to get the hang of it-Fun to play for hours on end-First person coasters-Great enviornment-Tons of carnival rides, coaster types and food stalls make it different each time you playCons-Like I mentioned some small problems with coasters but nothing major as it can be fixedFinal Grade9.5/10 Great with tiny issues

												This simulation is that, a simulation. To treat it as a game is to treat railway simulator as a game. That said, if you like fairground rides, either have the creativity of building your own coaster or just developing your park so that it's running at peak efficiency, this is for you.having to Juggle selling a baby Zebra in order to go back into profit Vs condemming a baby zebra to abuse in a circus is a much easier decision on a simulation that in real life.Baby Zebra 2014-2015. Rip.Anyway, be careful buying this at full retail, RollerCoaster Tycoon: World is coming out on PC soon with a demon in Aug-sep 15 being shown publically. If it's on offer, snap this up, but do not pay full price due to the fact the next in line is due out soon.:)Tom

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: August 28, 2015
												After 20 hours its time for a reviewThis game right off the bat feels nostalgic. I never had the expansions so this is great. The start menu is a bit bland, just un-appealing photos but that doesnt matter.I got into the game and I instantley decided to make a wild west park, after hours of work I had my base park down a coaster and some carnival rides and I was hooked like I used to be. I decided to download some maps and they are great. Some cons are the fact that some coasters are odd to build, an example is on the tilt coaster on one of the special pieces instead of slowing down it keeps moving and crashes. Overall I see no reason not to buy this.Pros-Once you make 1 or 2 good coasters its easy to get the hang of it-Fun to play for hours on end-First person coasters-Great enviornment-Tons of carnival rides, coaster types and food stalls make it different each time you playCons-Like I mentioned some small problems with coasters but nothing major as it can be fixedFinal Grade9.5/10 Great with tiny issues

Posted: January 1, 2016
												I grew up playing RTC games, Loved playing them all. RTC3 is probably my favourite. Building your very own theme park based on selective themes such as; Horror, Fantasy, or Western just makes it all the fun rather than having a generic theme park. A good sandbox game for those who enjoy playing games with no limits, or just enjoy building and creating stuff. There is also campaign mode which I love as well. Having to complete certain things for a pre-made theme park, adding rides etc to it. This is game is for everyone and I reccommend this game.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 9, 2015
												I grew up playing RCT2, and RCT3 has been an utter delight for me. The merging of art, practical design and economic simulation makes for game that is as challenging as you want it to be, and tons of fun to play.Career mode gives this otherwise totally leisurely game a set of reasonably attainable goals that leave plenty of room for creative choice while at the same time pushes you to think creatively to make your coasters pack as much fun as possible into as little space as possible for as few dollars (or yen) as possible.Or, you could just kill them all as most reviewers suggest. Either way, this game is great and you should definitely make it a part of your collection if you can get into building sick roller coasters and themed parks/rides. the ability to add your own music to each ride or at loudspeakers anywhere you want in the park is a really nice touch. The ride-cam is probably the best part of the game.9.5/10, Awesome game. -0.5 for framerate issues but my computer is crap anyway so no biggie.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: May 19, 2015
												I've been playing RCT franchise on and off since it first came out when I was a child, mostly with a disk. Recently, I picked it back up with Steam. Clearly, my hours played don't truly represent how much I've been playing this game for the last decade or so. A lot of reviews will be by people who do not have the patience and imagination to really get into it. There are a lot of complaints about the cartoonish graphics to RCT3. A lot of people see this and start just crashing the coasters a lot and then say "doesn't replay well," or try to do a little tinkering with the program files without really knowing how the game works and then say it's really buggy. Ignore these reviews, if you have patience it is probably the best Theme Park simulator out there, especially for those who haven't played theme park simulators very much before. It's obviously not built for the hardware that most gamers have today, so it can be a little buggy if you don't know what you're doing. But that's not the fault of the game, and with a tiny bit of tinkering and careful patience it runs excellently even on my Windows 8.1 64-bit OS, a SSD, and an Intel I-7 processor. The best way to play the game is to get connected to the fantastic community that has been playing it for so long. The RCT3 community on Steam is, to say the least, not very good. The best place to see this game's real potential is to go to the following sites:http://rctgo.com/http://www.shyguysworld.com/Much of the community is beginning to move on in the last year or so thanks to the anticipated release of RCTWorld later this year, and the much acclaimed Theme Park Studio. However, RCTWorld won't likely be as well-supported as RCT3 has been for the last decade and Theme Park Studio is not the best for beginners to the genre. Regardless of the competition, RCT3 is still a great use of your $20 if you're interested in getting into this genre.The best way to play the game is to download the massive collection of third-party add-ons, typically called Custom Scenery (or CS). It can be overwhelming, but like similar old games with a community following (such as Sim City 4), CS is surprisingly well organized. For example:http://www.customscenerydepot.com/cslist/In short, after a decade I still keep coming back to this game. It's definitely worth your money and time if you do your homework and learn the ins and outs of this game well.

Posted: May 23, 2015
												Simply put, this is my favorite game of all time. It was one of the first games I ever played, and it was on a CD from the library which I got a week at a time. I played it each week for many weeks. Nevermind what Steam says, I probably have 300+ hours into this game, and that was before the expansion packs. I don't think that it really needs to be explained, other than that the UI works nicely, the game runs nicely, the graphics fit the style, the music is fantastic, and the game is super easy to understand. Here's the thing: The game was amazing, then I discovered the pools DLC, then I discovered the animals DLC, and then I discovered the amazing online community and downloadable custom scenery. The game is the best I have ever played. However, if you are used to good graphics or lots of action, this game is not for you.

												This has become one of my favourite games very quickly. And it has good reason to...RCT3 allows you to build amazing and stupid roller coasters as much as you want to with a lot of customisation, including how fast the coasters go and what colour each part is.  The on-ride camera is an amazing feature which lets you see how good your roller coasters really are (and make you feel sick if you make them go as fast as I do!).The game may be old but it has aged well, the graphics might not look top-notch but it's not too noticeable. And I find that the game takes a long time too load (not everyone seems to get this problem).Overall, this is a game worth spending money on, it provides hours of entertainment and a huge choice of stuff to do.

content:
Posted: March 23, 2015
												I love this game. RollerCoaster Tycoon 3: Platinum adds the great idea of riding your rides after building them. It brings the world of RCT into 3D. The rides are great and are really fun to build. The AI of the people isn't great and there isn't a lot of scenery choices, but the rides make up for it. They improved the sandbox by making it its own thing instead of having to make a new custom scenario just for it. There are multiple carrer choices that each have one objective but after you complete the first, it makes it tougher by making you expand your goal even more. If you have trouble understanding how to play the game, there is a tutorial mode that will help you on your way to becoming the best rollercoaster park designer that you can be. I would fully recommend this game to anyone who has the time and patiece to make your park look great and making your rollercoasters amazing. This is one of my favorite games, which may seem sad, but it is that good. If you have the money to buy this game, get it right away.

content:
Posted: November 25, 2014
												RCT3, although a bit buggy, is a great park simulator game. It is very easy to pick up (and has tutorials for newcomers), and the Sandbox mode allows you to create large, expansive parks.Positives:-3D Graphics are great-Custom Music-Fun scenarios-Unlimited creation (I created an underground park, indoor park, and have seen creations such as cruise ships and cities)-Coaster cam is funNegatives:-A bit buggy-Runs slow on large parks (runs a lot better on Steam than from disk)-Limited scenery options-Unrealistic supports/scenery (download a scenery set of supports for more realism)-Lack of gentle ridesAlso note that I have many more than 12 hours on this game, as I originally purchased this game on release day, as well as its expansions, before purchasing it on Steam years later.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: September 23, 2014
												A classic. The most in-depth amusement park simulator out there, RCT3 is a game that really should be in every Steam member's library. The ability to micromanage every milimeter of your park (and the ability to keep things mostly in broad strokes instead) is something that most can appreciate, and the sandbox mode is fun. I imagine for a lot of people the fun will mostly be had in designing their own parks-slash-horrible murder cesspools, but there are three well-made single player campaigns. The difficulty curve is all over the place (The notoriously nigh-impossible La La Land scenario is somewhere in the middle of the main campaign), but the design of the parks are nice.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: September 22, 2014
												So yeah, Roller Coaster Tycoon. What can you even say about it really? It's a classic game series that pretty much boosted tycoon games (Other than Sim City) to more heights. So with the passage of time, Infograms we're bought out by atari and the original creator, Chris Sawyer, not working on it anymore, Atari tried to make there own RCT game; and this is how Roller Coaster Tycoon 3 came to be known as... an okay game.So I guess I have to say the pros and cons about it, soooooooooooooooooooooo...The game is now in 3D, and it works pretty well. The only real problem is trying to turn the camera up and down trying to find the perfect angle; It just resets and goes back to a semi top down perspective. The main focus of the game is that you can RIDE the RIDES, and you can kinda ride the rides, but not in the people or "peep's" point of view. Instead It's on the cart's point of view. Because the rides have feelings too you know. The gameplay is you're tipical tycoon game. But don't go building your rollercoaster of death and spooky scary skeletons, you see this game has an antagonist. The Park Inspector. He hate's everything fun and will make you throw out your anger on the keyboard. You're roller coaster is a little bit unsafe? SHUT IT DOWN! Water slide landing in the wrong pool? SHUT IT DOWN! He really makes the game less fun and you can't take him out. Also, you can't kill people in the game. I guess it makes the game more casualized since there's no worry of screwing up your coaster. Oh and one more thing to add. The zoo expansion is just Zoo Tycoon so just ask someone how Zoo Tycoon plays and that's RCT 3's Zoo expansion in a nutshell. The Water expansion just adds pools which don't really need an explanation. Same with Water Slides.So yeah, It's an okay game but not as good as the other games in the series. Really, if it was it's own game without the RCT game I think I would have liked it more, not to say It's a bad game. But with the price, I don't recommend it. Wait for a sale to get it, trust me you'll thank me later.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 28, 2013
												I'm amazed they never made a sequel to this. This is by far the most in depth theme park construction kit ever. It gives you the option of using easy prebuilt rides and scenery if you only feel like moving forward in the Career mode, but it also allows you to use an insane amount of custom tools and options if you feel like adding a quick flair to something or even if you want to build something special and unique from the ground up. The sandbox mode let's you experiment with or without restraint to that end.The atmosphere in this game needs to be seen and heard to be understood, it's a work of gesamtkunstwerk. Everything in this game is unified into that mode of play that only a day at a theme park seems to have, whether that's in the middle of summer without a cloud in the sky or in the middle of October when it drizzles often and every theme park brings out it's vampire costumes and spider webs. The music is especially expressive of this theme.If that's not enough, RCT 3: Platinum gives you the option to use music and pictures from your own library to use seamlessly in the park! If you just want to play a light-hearted tycoon game it's in there, if you want to spend time building a roller coaster that weaves in and out of a pirate ship while it's under attack by another pirate ship that also has a syncronized seperate roller coaster in it that uses a unique soundtrack and an accompanying fireworks display, it's also in there with tutorials. Be careful though, after a while of the former you might find yourself getting sucked into the latter.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 26, 2013
												Without a single doubt, RCT3 is a time consuming, coaster building, amusement gaining good time. Though a few things that made RCT2 unique are not present in this one, there's still more than enough to settle for. The game comes with all the expansion packs; Soaked, and Wild, both with an acceptable amount of new features. The transition to 3D looks rather dated up close, but from a distance it appears to look similar to some tycoon games on the new market today, but of course this would be the least graphically advanced of the bunch. Though campaigns are laughably shorter than the previous titles, this feels like a good move because something the previous installments lacked was the ability to keep the player caring on a single map with the limited choices to make for around four hours on a first run. Instead, you'll be on a map for around a good hour and that's the perfect amount of time you need before it begins to get dull. When you move to another map, the experience is always renewed because of how many new options you obtain. Sandbox mode is here for new players to experiment around with endless money and restrictions, so you can jump right in and learn for yourself. Tutorial sessions are also available. Replayability is a sweet refreshment to this game because the Platinum edition itself is around a good 35 hours, and with the ability to be creative on sandbox, complete all the tycoon challenges, and the map editor (you heard me right!) the game will never get old. If you can get over it's childish appeal, (and as an "unmentioned" comment, the land editing mechanics) it's here to give you literally endless hours of solid entertainment.8.5/10

												This is my alltime favorite rollercoaster builder. There's a tutorial to learn, sandboxmode and a campaign. Graphics are outdated but who cares. Its all about the gameplay and this game brings out the best thinkable gameplay for building a rollercoaster park combined with soaked attractions and wildlife attractions. Pros:- Freedom to build your own coasters or swimming paradise how you want it.- Graphics are from 2006 and most computers can run this game.- This Ultimate versoin contains RT3 + Soaked + Wildlife = a lot of value for a low priceCons:- The guided tutorials are semi guided and the interaction between the steps and the actions you perform are not all automated like we see in games that are more recent.- Graphics feel outdated compared to what's out on the marketI highly recommend this game if you are into themeparks and such. It's still a lot better then newer games that have better graphics but a whole different approach on gameplay and the lack of freedom to build things the way you want.

												This is one of my favorite games of all time! After completing everything in the game I assure you it's definitely satisfying. RollerCoaster Tycoon fans seem to maybe not like this game but there are settings to please those players back in the early 00s. The game excels in pretty much every aspect such as improved objective structure, VIPs, Peep Editors, and Coasters such as the Splitting coaster and Tilt coaster (Check those out). There's also now a sandbox mode so you can truly do whatever the hell you want. People are scared of bears.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 14, 2011
												One of the most addictive RTS games in the Tycoon franchise. Though the graphics feel dated, the mechanics are so immersive you quickly set the visuals aside as you're pulled further and further into the life of living at an amusement park. Hundreds of different rides, stands, objects and items, you can construct your own buildings using thousands of in-game pieces, even orchestrate a complex fireworks/laser show. Create an intense coaster, and then ride it thanks to the coaster cam. With so many different things up for offer, so many variations and so many gameplay modes, you'll never get bored with it. If you've ever wanted to build your very own rollercoaster and/or have any interest in RTS games (or played either of the previous two installments), look no further. 9 / 10

												Wow, this game... Sure, it has flaws, sure, the grid is a little annoying but once you get around those flaws, it is so amazing! This game gives you management, strategy, simulation, and yet there is still SO much creativity involved in the game. Games like this are hard to find these days. This game will go perfect beside RTC1 and 2. Games like this will leave you addicted for months if not years! I used to play this game off steam since i got the CD in 2006 and it played over 1000 hours and never got bored! This is one of my favorite games of all time!
